解释器不一样？
广义上解释器是一个，就是GH的 [markdown](https://guides.github.com/features/mastering-markdown/)处理器。

以上三种代码嵌入都是合法的。显示出来的东西由GH markdown 处理器决定。

如果我们直接用没有代码类型的引用，就没有关键词颜色。如果代码类型错误，就可能有错误警告，比如红色背景等等。

```javascript
1. Item 1
2. Item 2
3. Item 3
   
```

```javascript
alert('thanks @all')
```
大家把[这里面所有的例子](https://guides.github.com/features/mastering-markdown/)都敲一遍放在这里，不许拷贝粘贴。不要怕出错，也不要怕评论多。光看不写是不行的。别人会不意味你们自己会。

It is very easy to make some works ** bold** and other words *italic* with Markdown. You can even [link to Google!](http://google.com)

Now you can see the importance of test before you commit. The Preview tab of GH editor will save you a lot of time if you use it to test. (You can right click the link to open it in another tab to test if the link is what you wanted.)

可靠才有效率。
It's very easy to make some words **bold** and other words *italic* with Markdown. You can even [link to Google!](http://google.com)

Sometimes you want numbered lists:

1. One
2. Two
3. Three

Sometimes you want bullet points:

* Start a line with a star
* Profit!

Alternatively,

- Dashes work just as well
- And if you have sub points, put two spaces before the dash or star:
  - Like this
  - And this

If you want to embed images, this is how you do it:

![Image of Yaktocat](https://octodex.github.com/images/yaktocat.png)

# Structured documents

Sometimes it's useful to have different levels of headings to structure your documents. Start lines with a `#` to create headings. Multiple `##` in a row denote smaller heading sizes.

### This is a third-tier heading

You can use  one `#` all the way up to `######` six for different heading sizes.

If you'd like to quote someone, use the > character before the line:

> Coffee. The finest organic suspension ever devised... I beat the Borg with it.
> - Captain Janeway

GitHub supports many extras in Markdown that help you reference and link to people. If you ever want to direct a comment at someone, you can prefix their name with an @ symbol: Hey @kneath — love your sweater!

But I have to admit, tasks lists are my favorite:

- [x] This is a complete item
- [ ] This is an incomplete item

When you include a task list in the first comment of an Issue, you will see a helpful progress bar in your list of issues. It works in Pull Requests, too!

And, of course emoji! :sparkles: :camel: :boom:

无序号：

- 使用破折号
- 分论点时，星号或破折号前加两个空格：
  - 破折号分论点一
  - 破折号分论点二
* 星号
  * 星号分论点一
  * 星号分论点二

3、image
添加图像：
![me](http://double126.github.io/project/html-element/images/life.jpg)

# Markdown

## Text
It's very easy to make some words **bold** and other words *italic* with Markdown. You can even [link to Tesla!](https://www.teslamotors.com/)

## Lists
Sometimes you want numbered lists:

1. One
2. Two
3. Three

Sometimes you want bullet points:

* Start a line with a star
* Profit!

Alternatively,

- Dashes work just as well
- And if you have sub points, put two spaces before the dash or star:
  - Like this
  - And this

## Images
If you want to embed images, this is how you do it:

![Image of BigData](http://img1.gtimg.com/tech/pics/hv1/188/26/1588/103266518.png)

## Headers & Quotes
Sometimes it's useful to have different levels of headings to structure your documents. Start lines with a `#` to create headings. Multiple `##` in a row denote smaller heading sizes.

### This is a third-tier heading

You can use  one `#` all the way up to `######` six for different heading sizes.

If you'd like to quote someone, use the > character before the line:

> Coffee. The finest organic suspension ever devised... I beat the Borg with it.
> - Captain Janeway

## Code
There are many different ways to style code with GitHub's markdown. If you have inline code blocks, wrap them in backticks: `var example = true`.  If you've got a longer block of code, you can indent with four spaces:

    if (isAwesome){
      return true
    }

GitHub also supports something called code fencing, which allows for multiple lines without indentation:

```
if (isAwesome){
  return true
}
```

And if you'd like to use syntax highlighting, include the language:

```javascript
if (isAwesome){
  return true
}
```
**Different languages for "Hello world"**

```Awk
BEGIN { print "Hello, world!" }
```
```C
#include <stdio.h>
int main()
{
    printf("Hello World!/n");
    return 0;
}
```

```C++
#include <iostream.h>
int main()
{
    cout<<"Hello World!"<<endl;
    return 0;
}
```

```Java
class Hello
{
    public static void main(String ars[])
    {
        System.out.print("Hello World!\n");
    }
}
```

```Lua
print "Hello World!\n"
```

```Perl
print "Hello World!\n"
```

```Python
print "Hello World!\n"
```

```Tcl
puts "Hello World!"
```
## Extras
GitHub supports many extras in Markdown that help you reference and link to people. If you ever want to direct a comment at someone, you can prefix their name with an @ symbol: Hey @ontouchstart   — Appreciate your selfless spirit ! and @safedata — Thanks for your supervision!
***It's an easter egg for you.***

But I have to admit, tasks lists are my favorite:

- [x] This is a complete item
- [ ] This is an incomplete item

When you include a task list in the first comment of an Issue, you will see a helpful progress bar in your list of issues. It works in Pull Requests, too!

And, of course emoji! :sparkles: :camel: :boom:

# 一级标题
一级内容
## 二级标题
二级内容
### 三级标题
三级内容
#### 四级标题
四级内容
##### 五级标题
五级内容
###### 六级标题
六级内容

> hello
> We're living the future so
> the present is our past.

@farname 你上面的那一段想做什么？

我猜可能是你想写个复杂的表格，里面每一项是代码， 对不对？似乎markdown的功能还不足够做到这一点。那没有关系。但是这个练习的目的是让你把所有markdown的例子都**亲自动手敲一遍**。我不反对尝试新的高难度的东西，但是基本的要学会。

即使你挑战高难度的东西，也不要做到一半就撂下。至少应该写清楚你到底想要做什么。结论是什么。哪怕你的结论是“markdown做不了你想做的东西就不值得一学”也行。你写的东西是给大家读的，不只是老师一个人。

我们这个课程的目的是大家互相学习交流。我们鼓励创新。但是首先要学会熟悉环境和与大家交流。没有人生来就是专家，比其他人高一等的。

希望大家珍惜这个难得的开放合作的学习机会。欢迎对话。
